newsitem.title: USA: U.S. space agency may extend shuttle mission.
newsitem.headline: U.S. space agency may extend shuttle mission.

text.p: The flight of shuttle Atlantis may be extended by one day so astronauts can repeat a test of a space exercise machine, officials said on Saturday.

The shuttle crew first ran a test of the treadmill device before docking with Russia's Mir station on Tuesday, but ground controllers later discovered that a laptop computer had failed to record the treadmill's performance.
The exercise device, which is designed to minimise vibration which could ruin sensitive microgravity experiments, is supposed to be used aboard the future international space station.
The shuttle crew were to repeat the treadmill test after Atlantis departs Mir on Sunday, but if they encounter problems, an extra day may be necessary to complete the test.
"We'll decide Monday morning whether we will actually add that day or not," mission operations director Bob Castle said at news conference.
The weather forecast for the shuttle's planned Florida landing would be an important factor in that decision, he said.
Atlantis was due to return to earth on Wednesday when the weather was expected to be good, but conditions were to deteriorate the following day.
"The weather would argue to not extend," Castle said. "But this is a pretty advanced forecast and that's why we'd like to wait as late as we can to decide whether to extend or not."
The shuttle and Mir crews were nearing the end of their joint work. Only 15-20 items needed to be moved between the two craft before the shuttle undocked on Sunday night.
Atlantis will leave behind astronaut Jerry Linenger for a four-month stay on Mir. His predecessor, John Blaha, will return to earth aboard the shuttle.
At the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida, structural engineers were examining the launch platform of space shuttle Discovery on Saturday to check it is safe for a planned Feb. 11 blastoff.
The inspections were ordered after a 24-ft-long crack appeared in the platform on Friday as the shuttle was being moved to its launch pad. Also, doors within the massive structure jammed.
Discovery was being readied for a mission to refurbish the Hubble Space Telescope.
